author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Manzoor Ahtesham, Writer Who Brought Bhopal to Life, Dies at 73
description: He focused with forensic precision on his native city, which was marked by an industrial tragedy in 1984. He was among the thousands in India to die of Covid-19 in the last few weeks.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: The Art Party Circuit Comes Roaring Back at Frieze New York
description: But even Michael R. Bloomberg, whose name graces the building, got stuck outside the Shed until he provided the proper Covid documentation.
content: Nouriel Roubini, the economist who in 2007 became known as Dr. Doom after predicting the collapse of the housing market, actually sounded ebullient about the future of New York City Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Lyn Macdonald, Who Preserved Voices of World War I, Dies at 91
description: “The recording angel of the common soldier,” she chronicled the war in seven books from the soldiers’ perspective, drawing on 600 interviews with veterans.
content: Mistakenly, they called it the war to end all wars, a grinding collision of empires and nations from 1914 to 1918 that robbed the young of their youth in the mud-bound reaches of Flanders, the Somme and many other fields of battle. Its course and impact inspired a vast canon of military history and increasingly bleak verse from the trenches.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Confusing Signals in April’s Labor Data
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 8, 2021.
content: “It turns out it’s easier to put an economy into a coma than wake it up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Seminara
title: Roger Federer on His New Gig: Swiss Tourism Spokesman
description: In his new role, the tennis champion and avowed chocolate lover, shares favorite places to hike, play tennis and eat in his home country.
content: Roger Federer, the Swiss 20-time Grand Slam champion, recently became an unpaid spokesman for Switzerland Tourism. In a Zoom call from his home in Switzerland’s Graubünden canton, he explained why travelers should visit his country when it reopens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: As Texas Voting Restrictions Near Passage, Democrats Stage Protest
description: The former presidential aspirants Beto O’Rourke and Julián Castro spoke to a crowd demonstrating outside the State Capitol.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — A day after the Texas House of Representatives voted to make it harder to cast a ballot in a state that already has some of the nation’s most restrictive voting laws, leading Democrats and hundreds of supporters gathered outside the State Capitol on Saturday to protest against legislation steaming toward approval in the Republican-led Legislature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: N.C.A.A. Chief, Pressured by State Laws, Pushes to Let Athletes Cash In
description: Five states are poised to allow college athletes to profit from their fame starting on July 1, and the N.C.A.A.’s leader says the association is preparing to respond.
content: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — The University of Miami has long been able to make a glossy pitch to the students it hopes will star on its sports teams: an exceptional athletic tradition, respected academics, South Florida’s sun-kissed glamour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John F. Wasik
title: 7 Steps to Take Now to Catch Up on Retirement Savings
description: Even if your finances weren’t devastated by the pandemic recession, many Americans have not yet started saving. Here’s what you can do.
content: For millions of retirement savers, the pandemic was a gut punch. There was the jarring stock market drop in March 2020, then millions lost their jobs, health insurance and ability to fund their savings. It was a financial catastrophe for many Americans — and they may not recover for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon drop us off in the Paleolithic wilderness with our mothers, but of course everything turns out fine.
content: ACROSTIC — Happy Mother’s Day! I just got my second dose of vaccine and read Margaret Renkl’s Mother’s Day essay in short order, so I’m feeling a bit weepy. These are emotional times! Thank goodness we have Team Cox/Rathvon to put things into a macrocosmic perspective on humanity and motherhood, courtesy of a passage from “Mothers and Others: The Evolutionary Origins of Mutual Understanding,” by Sarah Blaffer Hrdy, an evolutionary anthropologist. The excerpt describes societal guidance for early people — hunter-gatherers — laid down by the matriarchs of the group: selflessness, congeniality, generosity, humbleness. After you finish it, you’ll think to yourself: “Well, of course that’s how society should work. I knew that already.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Is Capitalism Killing Conservatism?
description: The conservative responses to stagnation and decay are incoherent and insufficient. But do liberals have any?
content: The report on Wednesday that U.S. birthrates fell to a record low in 2020 was expected but still grim. On Twitter the news was greeted, characteristically, by conservative laments and liberal comments implying that it’s mostly conservatism’s fault — because American capitalism allegedly makes parenthood unaffordable, work-life balance impossible and atomization inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Alabama Police Officer Is Convicted of Murdering a Suicidal Man
description: Jeffrey Parker had called 911 to report that he was suicidal and was holding a gun to his head when he was fatally shot by Officer William Darby, prosecutors said.
content: A police officer in Huntsville, Ala., was convicted of murder on Friday for fatally shooting a man who had called 911 to report that he was suicidal and who was holding a gun to his head when the police arrived, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Making of a Goal Machine
description: Bayern’s Robert Lewandowski is the most complete, most ruthless, most polished striker of his generation. But what we see is only the finished product.
content: Robert Lewandowski does not characterize it as thought. Not conscious thought, anyway. In those moments when he has the ball at his feet and the goal in his sights, even after all these years, even when he can lay claim to being the most complete, most ruthless, most polished striker of his generation, he is not thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Where Ukrainians Are Preparing for All-Out War With Russia
description: A dried-up canal running from Ukraine into Russian-occupied Crimea is emerging as one of Europe’s main flash points.
content: KALANCHAK, Ukraine — A makeshift dam of sand and clay, covered with patches of grass, blocks one of Europe’s great canals. Beyond it, swans drift in the trickle of water that remains. A duck slides into a wall of reeds below the bare, concrete banks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Immigration Courts Aren’t Real Courts. Time to Change That.
description: As long as these judges are subject to political pressures, there can be no true judicial process.
content: President Biden took office with a promise to “restore humanity and American values” to the immigration system. If he’s going to succeed, it will take more than shutting down construction on his predecessor’s border wall. The most formidable obstacle to making the U.S. immigration system more humane and functional is invisible to most Americans: the nation’s broken, overwhelmed immigration court system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Bo, the Obamas’ Portuguese Water Dog, Dies
description: Former President Barack Obama said the family had lost “a true friend and loyal companion.”
content: Bo, the Portuguese water dog who became the first presidential pet in the Obama White House, romping in the halls of power, died on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Jaleel White Wants to Sell You ‘Purple Urkle’
description: Mr. White hopes to see more Black and Latino people leading cannabis brands and businesses.
content: Fifteen states, as well as Washington, D.C., have legalized recreational marijuana use, with New York among the most recent state to adopt such a measure. That bill, signed into law last month by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, included significant provisions to address issues of racial equity, such as clearing criminal records of past convictions for marijuana-related offenses and earmarking 40 cents of every dollar in tax revenue from cannabis sales for the communities that have been hardest hit by the consequences of drug enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Sameer Yasir, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Atul Loke
title: At India’s Funeral Pyres, Covid Sunders the Rites of Grief
description: Mourners in protective gear, or watching from home. Long waits at the cremation grounds. The trauma of loss has become both lonely and public.
content: NEW DELHI — The lifeless are picked up from infected homes by exhausted volunteers, piled into ambulances by hospital workers or carried in the back of auto-rickshaws by grieving relatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Is Liz Cheney a Martyr — or Just a Hack in Holy Drag?
description: Some political questions defy any easy answer.
content: No sooner had I become overwhelmed by the corpulent body of journalism about Liz Cheney as some beacon of moral clarity than I began to feel besieged by dissents about what a wretched opportunist she really is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Evictions in Jerusalem Become Focus of Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
description: The effort to evict six Arab families from a contested neighborhood has drawn attention to the Israeli effort to remove Palestinians from parts of East Jerusalem and led to protests.
content: JERUSALEM — In confrontations with Palestinian protesters over the past week in Sheikh Jarrah, a Palestinian neighborhood in East Jerusalem, the Israeli police sprayed so much skunk water, a noxious liquid used to deter demonstrators, that its stench lingered over nearby streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: These Neanderthals Weren’t Cannibals, So Who Ate Them? Stone Age Hyenas.
description: An archaeological excavation south of Rome uncovered fossil remains of nine Neanderthals, along with the bones of hyenas, elephants and rhinoceroses.
content: ROME — When a Neanderthal skull was discovered in a cave on the property of a beachfront hotel south of Rome in 1939, it prompted a theory, since debunked, that Neanderthals had engaged in ritual cannibalism, extracting the brains of their victims to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Cleric Lifts Iraq’s Faltering Vaccination Effort, but Perilous Summer Awaits
description: The popular cleric Moktada al-Sadr got a coronavirus vaccine, persuading many of his followers to do the same. Yet millions of Iraqis remain unconvinced.
content: BAGHDAD — In a country where most people believe that God will protect them but their government won’t, it has taken a popular Shiite cleric to give Iraq’s stumbling vaccination program a boost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Grand Canyon Hike Organizer Violated Covid-19 Restrictions, Officials Say
description: Prosecutors said at least 150 people showed up, astounding rangers and overwhelming visitors who struggled to steer clear of the hikers, many of whom were not wearing masks or social distancing.
content: The organizer of a Grand Canyon adventure described it as a chance to trek along the South Rim, “one of the greatest hikes in the planet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Tawny Kitaen, Star of 1980s Music Videos, Dies at 59
description: Ms. Kitaen gained fame for her carefree spirit and sultry dancing in music videos for bands like Whitesnake and Ratt and her role in the movie “Bachelor Party.”
content: Tawny Kitaen, an actress who gained fame in the 1980s for her roles in rock music videos and who starred with Tom Hanks in the movie “Bachelor Party,” died on Friday at her home in Newport Beach, Calif. She was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cheap Cab, Perhaps
description: David Steinberg returns to us with an intoxicating Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — For mid- to long-term solvers, isn’t it so nice to see the gentle genius of David Steinberg on a weekend again? He juggles a lot of puzzle projects while wearing editing hats, but it has been a while — almost two years since his last (24th) Saturday grid (which makes this puzzle a bit of a milestone: 25).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: I’m the Executor of My Mother’s Estate. What Happens if Her Stuff Doesn’t Sell?
description: Executors are expected to make prudent decisions about how to liquidate an estate, but what if it’s not as valuable as they think?
content: Q: I’m the executor of my mother’s estate. The sale of her house and its belongings will be divided evenly among her surviving children. I had the home’s furnishings appraised and am preparing them for sale. What happens if some of the items do not sell? Or if they sell for far less than the appraised value? As the executor, would I be personally liable for any shortfalls and be expected to pay my siblings the difference?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchika Tulshyan
title: ‘You’ve Lost Your Sparkle’: What to Do When Burnout Hits
description: Dr. Yumiko Kadota, a surgeon in Sydney, and the author of “Emotional Female,” on stress, burnout and toxic work environments.
content: — Yumiko Kadota, the author of “Emotional Female”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Orange
title: Trying to Imagine Post-Pandemic Life? Virginia Woolf and Toni Morrison Can Help.
description: “To the Lighthouse” and “Beloved” suggest how to envision a world we might actually want to re-enter.
content: A lesser mystery of the pandemic: how to square the rise in total book sales (roughly 10 percent in 2020) and the number of readers (roughly all of them) who over that same period described the struggle to conquer a single paragraph, much less all, of “Middlemarch.” A year of dread, loss and social tumult has stretched at both ends the extent to which taking a new book in hand constitutes an act of hope. If the ability to immerse oneself in another world has wavered, it would appear that the will to do so endures, bound up, for now, in the piles of un- and half-read books fortifying our respective holding cells.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seeing the Real Faces of Silicon Valley
description: For many midlevel engineers and food truck workers and longtime residents, a region filled with extremes has become increasingly inhospitable.
content: The workers of Silicon Valley rarely look like the men idealized in its lore. They are sometimes heavier, sometimes older, often female, often darker skinned. Many migrated from elsewhere. And most earn far less than Mark Zuckerberg or Tim Cook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Canelo Álvarez Is Back, and Boxing Is Back to Its Usual Uncertainty
description: Beyond Álvarez’s bout on Saturday night with Billy Joe Saunders, it is not very clear where boxing is headed. Thank the sport’s usual gamesmanship.
content: Four days before Saul Álvarez and Billy Joe Saunders were scheduled to meet in a high-stakes boxing match at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, organizers were giddy over the ticket sales projections for their super-middleweight title fight on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Remember the Homeless Chess Champion? The Boy Is Now a Chess Master.
description: A soaring chess prodigy is a reminder: Talent is universal, but opportunity is not.
content: Once upon a time a 7-year-old refugee living in a homeless shelter sat down at a chess board in school and learned how to play. His school then agreed to his mom’s plea to waive fees for him to join the chess club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish, Rebecca R. Ruiz and David Gelles
title: The Separate Worlds of Bill and Melinda Gates
description: They built an empire that was essential in the pandemic. Now, their impending divorce makes personal a shift that confidants say was well underway in their philanthropic roles.
content: Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates were stuck at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: 4 Dead in Shooting and Fire Near Baltimore, Police Say
description: Two men and one woman died after a shooting and a townhouse fire, which were related, officials said. The police fatally shot the gunman.
content: Four people died, including a gunman who was shot by the police, after officers and firefighters responded to reports of a shooting and a two-alarm fire on Saturday in Baltimore County, Md., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: Learning to Be a Mother Can Take Generations — and Sometimes, Distance
description: Times readers weigh in on the magic and complications of grandmothers.
content: “The human grand-maternal relationship is nearly unique in the natural world,” writes Abigail Tucker, a science writer, in a guest essay for Opinion. For new mothers in particular who are lucky enough to have their own mothers at hand, there are “tremendous benefits to our mental health and maternal behavior in ways that emerging science increasingly underscores.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Lauren Hard
title: Cases plunge in Puerto Rico, prompting a gradual rollback of restrictions.
description: Strict measures in early April and rising vaccinations have helped lower the U.S. territory’s new daily cases by more than 60 percent over the past two weeks.
content: The number of coronavirus cases in Puerto Rico is declining precipitously after soaring to record heights in March and April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Youyou Zhou
title: Do Restrictions on H-1B Visas Create American Jobs?
description: Demand for the visas has increased despite Trump administration policies that made them less likely to be approved.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim
title: Bombing Outside Afghan School Kills at Least 50, With Girls as Targets
description: The attack, which came at the end of a particularly violent week, underlined growing concerns about the American troop withdrawal.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Powerful explosions outside a high school in Afghanistan’s capital on Saturday killed at least 50 people and wounded scores more, many of them teenage girls leaving class, in a gruesome attack that underscored fears about the nation’s future after the impending American troop withdrawal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Marooned at Mar-a-Lago, Trump Still Has Iron Grip on Republicans
description: The vilification of Liz Cheney and a bizarre vote recount in Arizona showed the damage from his assault on a bedrock of democracy: election integrity.
content: Locked out of Facebook, marooned in Mar-a-Lago and mocked for an amateurish new website, Donald J. Trump remained largely out of public sight this week. Yet the Republican Party’s capitulation to the former president became clearer than ever, as did the damage to American politics he has caused with his lie that the election was stolen from him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: ‘This Is Politics’: Dr. Rachel Levine’s Rise as Transgender Issues Gain Prominence.
description: President Biden’s assistant secretary for health is the highest-ranking openly transgender person ever to serve in the federal government.
content: WASHINGTON — Dr. Rachel Levine was not a particularly aggressive football player at the elite all-boys school she attended in Massachusetts four decades ago. She loved drama and glee club, but when it came to football, she said, “I told the coach, ‘Well, I’ll tackle, but I don’t want to hurt them.’ ”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: Jake Tapper’s Hero Is Embedded With the Rat Pack, Hoping to Catch a Rat
description: Tapper’s new thriller, “The Devil May Dance,” plumbs the connections among Hollywood, the Mafia and the Kennedy administration.
content: Janet Leigh, movie star, is in the ladies’ room at Toots Shor’s when a zoologist named Margaret Marder runs into her. The year: 1962. The occasion: a wrap party for “The Manchurian Candidate” thrown by another of its stars, Frank Sinatra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: What Will We Do With Our Masks Now?
description: As more people are vaccinated and guidelines around mask wearing are easing, some are finding ways to preserve, repurpose and recycle their face coverings.
content: It first emerged as a sign — on faces in airports, at hospitals, on the streets — that this virus was not to be taken lightly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Karan Deep Singh
title: India and Its Vaccine Maker Stumble Over Their Pandemic Promises
description: The Serum Institute vowed to protect the country from Covid-19 and inoculate the world’s poor, but India’s crisis has pushed it past its limits.
content: NEW DELHI — Adar Poonawalla made big promises. The 40-year-old chief of the world’s largest vaccine maker pledged to take a leading role in the global effort to inoculate the poor against Covid-19. His India-based empire signed deals worth hundreds of millions of dollars to make and export doses to suffering countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Of Brexit and Boris: What’s Driving the Call for Scottish Independence
description: Scots voted to remain in the E.U., and they resent being dictated to by England. And they just plain don’t like Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
content: The millions of votes cast across Scotland Thursday could be among the most consequential in recent times, and not because of their impact on things like health, education and fisheries. The greatest issue facing the country, and the one that was really at stake, was nowhere to be found on the ballot, and that is the future of its 314-year-old union with England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ellen Barry and Will Wright
title: Ma’Khia Bryant’s Journey Through Foster Care Ended With an Officer’s Bullet
description: The 16-year-old girl was fatally shot while threatening a young woman with a knife. She had spent two years shuttling among Ohio foster homes, hoping to return to her mother.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The voice on the 911 call is a teenage girl’s, and it is quavering, as if she has been crying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Angelos
title: Was Nazi Germany Defeated or Liberated? Germans Can’t Decide.
description: It will be very dangerous if Germany starts to see itself as a victim of the Nazis.
content: BERLIN — Victory in Europe Day, the anniversary of Nazi Germany’s military capitulation to the Allies on May 8, 1945, is an occasion of unreserved celebration across much of the continent, observed with colorful parades and national holidays. For Germans, it is understandably fraught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Justice Dept. Seized Washington Post’s Phone Records
description: Federal prosecutors sought phone records for three Washington Post journalists as part of an investigation into the publication of classified information in 2017.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department under President Donald J. Trump secretly obtained the phone records for three reporters at The Washington Post from the early months of the Trump administration, the newspaper disclosed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Recipes to Knock Out in Under an Hour
description: No matter how much time you have to cook, we have a recipe that will fit your schedule.
content: If you’re in the market for new, quick recipes, our collection of the most popular recipes of the week has you covered. In just 45 minutes, you could have Melissa Clark’s one-pot braised chard with gnocchi, peas and leeks on the table. In 35 minutes, you could be pulling Eric Kim’s sheet-pan bibimbap from the oven, or Yewande Komolafe’s coconut fish and tomato bake (above) from the broiler. And in 30 minutes, Hetty McKinnon’s beet and lentil salad with Cheddar is ready for lunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Martin Bookspan, Cultured Voice of Lincoln Center Telecasts, Dies at 94
description: The longtime announcer for “Live From Lincoln Center,” he said he wanted his audience “to become involved, to love what they’re hearing.”
content: Martin Bookspan, who parlayed a childhood grounding in classical music into a career as the announcer for the “Live From Lincoln Center” telecasts and the radio broadcasts of the Boston Symphony and the New York Philharmonic, died on April 29 at his home in Aventura, Fla. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Scotland Election Results Complicate Hopes for Independence Referendum
description: The Scottish National Party fell short of an outright majority, though pro-independence parties appeared to retain control of Scotland’s Parliament.
content: LONDON — Hopes for a swift path to independence in Scotland were tempered on Saturday, as the dominant Scottish nationalist party fell one seat short of a majority in the country’s Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Lloyd Price, ‘Personality’ Hitmaker, Is Dead at 88
description: His “Lawdy Miss Clawdy” was a rhythm-and-blues smash that hooked white listeners in 1952, anticipating the rise of rock ’n’ roll. Even bigger records would follow.
content: Lloyd Price, who provided some of the seeds for what became rock ’n’ roll with his New Orleans rhythm-and-blues hit “Lawdy Miss Clawdy” in 1952 and later had major pop hits with “Personality” and “Stagger Lee,” died on Monday at an extended-care center in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Wade Miley Waits Out Delay and Throws Season’s Fourth No-Hitter
description: The Reds scored three runs in 9th to break 0-0 tie. The Mets won in extra innings and the Yankees got crushed.
content: Wade Miley pitched baseball’s second no-hitter in three days — and fourth already this season — leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 3-0 win Friday night over Cleveland, which was no-hit for the second time in a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: E-Commerce Mega-Warehouses, a Smog Source, Face New Pollution Rule
description: A plan aimed at the nation’s largest cluster of warehouses is designed to spur electrification of pollution-spewing diesel trucks and could set a template for restrictions elsewhere.
content: Southern California is home to the nation’s largest concentration of warehouses — a hub of thousands of mammoth structures, served by belching diesel trucks, that help feed America’s booming appetite for online shopping and also contribute to the worst air pollution in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Cruise Line Threatens to Skip Florida Ports Over Proof-of-Vaccination Ban
description: Norwegian Cruise Line plans to require Covid-19 vaccine documentation from its crew members and customers, but Florida recently enacted a law that bars businesses from doing so.
content: Norwegian Cruise Line is threatening to keep its ships out of Florida ports after the state enacted legislation that prohibits businesses from requiring proof of vaccination against Covid-19 in exchange for services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Clifford Krauss and Nicole Perlroth
title: Cyberattack Forces a Shutdown of a Top U.S. Pipeline
description: The operator, Colonial Pipeline, said it had halted systems for its 5,500 miles of pipeline after being hit by a ransomware attack.
content: One of the nation’s largest pipelines, which carries refined gasoline and jet fuel from Texas up the East Coast to New York, was forced to shut down after being hit by ransomware in a vivid demonstration of the vulnerability of energy infrastructure to cyberattacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Michael Levenson
title: 3 Shot, Including a 4-Year-Old, in Times Square, Police Say
description: The police said that the child, who was shot in the leg, as well as two other victims, both women, were expected to survive.
content: A fight among several men in Times Square on Saturday led at least one of them to pull out a gun and open fire, injuring two women and a 4-year-old girl, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Mother’s Day Concert
description: Brad Wiegmann delivers a tuneful puzzle performance.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Happy Mother’s Day! Brad Wiegmann is back so soon — does the name ring a bell? He was behind (pun intended) the nudist puzzle from February. That makes this puzzle fitting, in a way, because if anyone has seen you in your birthday suit it is certainly Mom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Melting Glaciers Have Exposed Frozen Relics of World War I
description: Artifacts from the White War — a battle between Italian and Austro-Hungarian troops that took place in the forbidding heights of the Alps — are on their way to a museum.
content: As glaciers melt and shrink in the Alps of Northern Italy, long-frozen relics of World War I have been emerging from the ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Liz Cheney and the Big Lies
description: Vice wasn't something she always worried about.
content: WASHINGTON — I miss torturing Liz Cheney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Kenneth Chang
title: China Says Debris From Its Rocket Landed Near Maldives
description: Most of the debris burned up on re-entry Sunday morning, China said. The head of NASA accused it of “failing to meet responsible standards.”
content: Debris from a large Chinese rocket landed in the Indian Ocean near the Maldives early Sunday morning, China’s space administration announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Shimabukuro
title: They Save the Day. (Every Day.) Six Moms on Their Super Powers.
description: A collection of essays curated by the Well desk features mothers acknowledging their special talents. Here, some of the team members join in.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Mars Helicopter Makes One-Way Flight to New Mission
description: Ingenuity has flown almost flawlessly through the red planet’s thin air and will now assist the science mission of the Perseverance rover.
content: This time, NASA’s Mars robotic helicopter Ingenuity did not come back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Jang
title: The Hidden Language of Mother’s Day Flowers
description: A tribute to mothers with the hidden language of flowers
content: A tribute to mothers with the hidden language of flowers
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Rothenberg
title: The Sound of Cicadas Is Music If You Take the Time to Listen
description: For cicadas and humans, it’s time to make music together.
content: For cicadas and humans, it’s time to make music together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Palestinians Protest Over Jerusalem Evictions
description: Palestinians protested ahead of a decision that will come from the Israeli Supreme Court on whether to uphold the eviction of six families from a neighborhood in East Jerusalem in favor of Jewish settlers.
content: Palestinians protested ahead of a decision that will come from the Israeli Supreme Court on whether to uphold the eviction of six families from a neighborhood in East Jerusalem in favor of Jewish settlers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 8, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 8, 2021.
content: An article this weekend on Page 6 about a cohort of prizewinning theater directors who are questioning the norms of their industry misattributes a comment by one of the directors interviewed. The quotation, “This has been an indescribably devastating time for our community, so I feel like we must say that very clearly. But I think, occasionally, with great hardship comes growth,” was said by Tyne Rafaeli, not Danya Taymor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Let’s Hear What High Schoolers Think
